Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £9 to Brindisi.
The combined Sea and special train fare has been reduced to £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.

During the Monsoon season the express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established 1899
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling
Price: One Plastre Tariff.
Tuesday, August 29, 1905
WAR AND PEACE.

The statement that Britain has signed a new treaty with Japan and is now working in favor of peace to such good purpose that the Conference may soon have fresh proposals to deal with must be received with caution, though there is every reason to hope that it is true. Japan could only be nduced to abate her very reasonable claim to be allowed to insure herself againt the dangers of another war, by the promise of support for a long period by a power capable of guaranteeing the integrity of Japan's insular possessions. Otherwise the Island Empire must fight on till Russia is forced to pay a huge indemnity rather than see the whole Siberian coast permanetly in the possession of the despised "makakis," or till Japan and Russia, financially exhausted and unable to inflict a decisive blow on one another, consent to a compromise. Neither alternative can possibly benefit England. The total overthrow of Russia and the seizure of a huge war indemnity by the conquerors, would completely upset the balance of power in East and West.

In Europe, though Russia might soon emerge strengthened and purified from the fires of revolution, it is far more probable that Germany would become undiputed lord of central Europe, would be able to dictate to France, and would have a free hand, should intestine troubles in Austria compel her to intervene. Japan would no doubt be enormously strengthened, but while it is our interest that Japan should be as strong as possible in her own, and Chinese waters, we no more share the enthusiasm of the many worthy persons who long to see the islanders masters of the Pacific, than we share that of the adulators of the United States, who throw up their caps and announce vociferously that the U. S. A. will soon be in possession of the second fleet in the world. The second fleet in the hands of a rich and well organised nation may well become the first, and while we have excellent reasons, both practical and sentimental, for wishing well both to the United States and to Japan, we cannot look forward with entire complacency to a large increase of the naval power of either. Just as France may be necessary to us, and we to France, as a counterpoise to the increase of German military and naval power, in the same way the presence of a weakened Russia and the Pacific Coast may one day be useful to the British Empire. We do not wish to be suspected of any hostility to Japan when we say that the temporary disappearance of any power from the field of international politics must be regarded as a calamity by our statesmen, and that while we have no wish to see Japan weakened in Asia (on the contrary a strong and porsperous Japan is a guarantee of Asiatic peace) we do not wish to see the obstinacy of her own rulers "bleed Russia white" in Europe, and perhaps, to alter the metaphor, blot her out as a Great Power for a generation. Exposed to attack in many parts of her vast Empire Britain cannot rely merely on her own stregth. She requires an ally-but she centerainly requires several potential enemies. One strong opponent is far harder to meet than an embarrassed coatition, and if we have two potential foes they are far more likely to come to terms with us than to fight. Such is the doctrine of the balance of Power which remains the mainspring of all British diplomacy. But it must not be supposed that British efforts on behalf of peace are entirely dictated by prudential reasons. Our king, who enjoys the personal friendship of many members of the Russian Imperial House, reflects the desires of the nation in his efforts to bring about a universal understanding between nations, and our statesmen doubtless share the detestation felt by every humane and reasonable man at the idea of a continuance fo the conflict. War may be as much a necessity to the nation as the pangs of travail to a mother, but the prolongation of the agony is what shocks the moral sense of mankind. At Portsmouth we have had a duel between statesmen who took up positions irreconcilable on certain points, and based such on a logical perception of his country's needs. We cannot blame M. de Witte for insisting on the preservation of Russian prestige, any more than we can blame Baron Komura for insisting on an indemnity. Meantime we can only hope against hope that in the eleventh hour sone means may be found of reconciling the adversaries in the bloodiest war that has taken place since the Napoleonic era closed.

The “Times” learns from Portsmouth (N.H.) that, according to a high Russian authority, a far stronger influence than President Roosevelt, namely England, is working for peace. A new treaty of alliance between England and Japan was signed not many days ago. This is one reason why new proposals may possibly be forthcoming at the Conference.
(Reuter)
The Conference was postponed until Tuesday at the request of Mi Takahira, who explained that he received nothing from Tokio.
(Reuter)

A prolonged conference of the Cabinet and the Elder Statesmen took place this morning. Subsequently the Ministers and Statesmen proceeded to the Palace, where they continued their deliberations under the presidency of the Emperor.
It is believed that the result of the conference will determine the issue of peace or war.
(Reuter)

It is reported that Japan on Thursday expressed her willingness to President Roosevelt to waive an indemnity or reimbursement, and to refer the question of the price of half the Saghalien Island to arbitration. This offer was misunderstood in St. Petersburg, hence the delay in the negotiations.
(Reuter)
M. Takahira, in the course of an interview, having been asked if the situation were hopeless, replied that it was not hopeless, but almost so.
(Reuter)
St. Petersburg, August 28.

A fight took place between Cossacks and 1,000 peasants armed with pitch-forks and bludgeons in the village of Inchadeedshara (Caucasus). It is officially admitted that 19 peasants were killed, but other accounts state that the casualties were 70.
(Reuter)
Riga, August 28.
The extensive mobilisation of reservists which is taking place here, at Windau, and other centres, is considered a significant point.
(Reuter)
St. Petersburg, August 29.
The Tsar in an Ukase on the 19th instant ordered mobilisation in thirteen Government Divisions in order to reinforce the Army in the Far East. This mobilisation is now preceding.
(Reuter)
Paris, August 28.
A French; semi-official note says that the Jerman reply introduces new elements, which leoessitate a further exohange of views regard- ng Morocco.
(Reuter)
SWIMEMUENDE, August 29.

The Channel Squadron arrived here the day efore yesterday and the active German fleet esterday. At a banquet given at the Kurhaus, ordial toasts were exchanged. The British nd German Admirals were present.
(Reuter)
SWIMEMUENDE, August 28.
The English Squadron has arrived. The lerman Squadron is going out to meet it.
(Havas)
Berlin, August 28.
The revolt in German East Africa is spreadg in the South. A sharp fight took place in the Kipo district, where 1,000 rebels, partly armed with rifles, were driven across the river.
(Reuter)
Paris, August 29.
A sensation has been caused by the suicide f the financier M. Crosnier, as a result of s isastrous speculation in sugar. His liabilities re estimated at £2,500,000.
(Reuter)
Paris, August 28.
M. Crosnier, president, of the Sugar Rafineries has committed suicide.
(Havas)

div.head: Stray and Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in the Bab-el-Sharieh quarter of Cairo during tomorrow night and at dawn of the 31st will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Furious Riding
div.p: A Customs Guard named Sayed Abou El Khair was knocked over by a horse, ridden at full gallop down Zaptieh street yesterday, and had to be taken to hospital.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 13 vessels passed through the Canal on the 25th inst„ of which 6 were British, 1 German, 3 Turkish, 1 American, 1 French, 1 Dutch. The day’s receipts were frs. 322, 115.65, making the total from the 1st inst., frs. 7,389,492.79.

div.head: An Omdeh Murdered
div.p: News comes from Tahta that the omdeh of Fazara has been murdered. It appears that his enemies lured him out of his house by raising a false alarm of fire, and then fired three shots at him which proved instantly fatal.

div.head: Train Fired at
div.p: Two shots were fired at the Helouan train the other day, but happily caused no damage as they both passed between the engine and the break van. The Tourah police were advised, and several went out in search of the offenders.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday’s plague bulletin reports one new admission to hospital and two deaths at Alexandria. The new case is a native boy of the Karmous district, and the two fatal cases are a native boy found dead at his house in the Gumruk quarter, and a Berberin saïs of tho Labban quarter.

div.head: Egyptian Athletics
div.p: A Pan-Egyptianathletic meeting has been organised by the Iphitos Gymastic Club of Cairo. The programme is the same as that of the Olympic games held at Athens, and all Egyptian athletic clubs are invited to compete at the meeting which will take place, under the distinguished patronage of M. Gennadis, on February 22, 1906.

div.head: Drowned in the Nile
div.p: On Sunday even- ing a native of Koronfish was making a pleasure trip on the Nile near Old Cairo with some friends whom he had invited, when his boat was run down and capsized. The unfortunate man was carried away by the current and drowned, but his friends were able to swim to shore.

div.head: Theft at Fagallah
div.p: A Syrian family living in the Fagallah quarter, Cairo, were surprised to find the door wide open on Sunday evening when they returned from a day’s outing. Several notes proved to have been taken from a drawer by a servant who had recently been dismissed, who is now being searched for by the police.

div.head: Export of Syrian Cattle
div.p: Precise orders have been issued to the customs authorities at Beyrout and Alexandretta to proibit the export of cattle used in husbandry, and of Angora goats. It appears that the number of cattle in the country has greatly decreased during the last two years owing to the prevalence of bovine typhus in some districts, and the fact that, in others the farmers took advantage of the Egyptian demand for ploughing and slaughter cattle to sell a majority of their stock at good prices.

div.head: Secret Policeman Shot
div.p: The condition of KamelEffendi Haneim of the secret police, who was shot in the forehead while attempting to arrest the Italian Camarato, who had already used his revolver against the police in the Gama’ el Ahmar quarter, Cairo, is still grave, though the symptoms are fairly satisfactory. Camarato, who appears to he a scoundrel of the lowest character, and his three companions have been arrested. We hope an example will be made of these ruffians, who provoked the interference of the police by a brutal attack on a woman.

div.head: An Insistant Woman
div.p: On the arrival of the M. M. S.S. Sénégal this morning a Syrian woman tried to push through the barrier before the vessel’s gangway had been put down. A shawish intervened whereupon the woman waxed wrathful and Administered two “smacks on the face” to the gallant policeman, who was only performing his duty. A police officer was called into the assistance of his subordinate, and was promptly treated in the same manner. A request to accompany her victims to the harbour police station was met with a refusal, the woman asserting that she was a free born British subject, but superior strength prevailed, and the caracol is now her temporary address.

div.head: Khedivial Yacht Club
div.p: Arrangements will be made that on the date of the anniversary of the Sultan’s Accession dinners will be given at the Club House at 8 p m. at the rate of 45 P.T. per head. Anyone wishing to dine must inform the Honorary Secretary not later than to-morrow Wednesday August 30th. after which date no further applications can be entertained. No privately organised dinner parties can be given at the Club on this date.

div.head: Entries for the deep sea race
div.p: to Aboukir and Back for which H.H. Prince Aziz Pasha has offered a handsome cup must be lodged with the Hon. Secretary not later than tomorrow, after the regatta. There will be no entrance. The conditions of the race will appear in our issue of to-morrow.

div.head: THE DAIBA SANIEH CASE. CLAUSES OF AGREEMENT.
div.p: In giving a brief resumé of the article on the action between the Princes of the Khedive Ismail's Family and the Daïra Sanieh which appeared in French in our issue of yesterday we will content ourselves with referring to those clauses of the agreement of June 21, 1898, of which chief mention is made.

By the contract of assignment of June 21, 1898, made between Sir Elwin Palmer, then Financial Adviser to H. H. the Khedive, duly authorised by the decision of the Council of Ministers, and a group of capitalists, the latter undertook to buy all the properties of the Daïra Sanieh, the obligation of which amounted to £6,431,500 on December 31, 1897.

The price of this acquisition was agreed upon at that sum, but in the terms of the first article there must “be deducted from this sum the amount at par of the bonds which will have been reimbursed from the date of December 31, 1897, until the date when the sale shall have become definite, and, on the other hand, to add to the price of purchase, the sums which the Egyptian Government will be required to pay to the Administration of the Daïra Sanieh by reason of eventual deficits.”

This sum was payable, against the handing over of all the properties of the Daïra Sanieh, on October 15, 1905, before which date the Government had undertaken not to extend its debt to the said Daïra.

By articles 5 and 6 the capitalists who signed the convention, or the society which might be formed by them, undertook to sell these properties within a period of seven years from their taking possession, and the Government had the right to half the net profits, which the capitalists, or company, would realise from the price of purchase.
By article 7 it was agreed that the capitalists, or company should deposit a guarantee of £500,000 at the Ministry of Finance, on August 1, 1868.

Article 8 provided that in the event of the purchase not being completed by October 15, 1905, the Government should acquire, ipso facto, the sum of £50,000 from the guarantee, but on the other hand, should the purchase be completed the guarantee should be returned.

Article 86 of the Law of liquidation provides that “from the date of publication of the present law, no person will be allowed before any magistracy for any cause or under any form whatsoever, to bring any action, he it against the Government, or against the Administrations of the State, by reason of the rights acquired previous to January 1, 1880.”

div.head: IMPORTANT DRAINAGE WORKS.
div.p: For more than a year extensive works have been in progress near Esbet Khorshid, which will greatly facilitate the drainage of the Central Lands of the Aboukir Co. Ltd. These works have been carried out by Mr. Williams, inspector of irrigation, and his staff. There is a large syphon under the Mahmoudieh Canal, built in brick and cement and of most solid construction, while under the railway there is a two-arch culvert. The waterway was opened two or three days ago, and drainage has now free course into Lake Mareotis.

The Aboukir Company had originally 30,000 feddans of which over 20,000 feddans are already reclaimed. The drainage system just inaugurated will enable the central lands to be rapidly and thoroughly reclaimed, and will create a well-drained tract of 10,000 feddans, which in a year or two will be one of the most valuable and compact blocks of land in Behera.

div.head: LAKE BOROULLOS.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary stated a few days ago that Ismail Pasha Sirri. inspector of the Projects Circle in the Ministry of Public Works, is spending his summer holiday in Holland in order that he may study the system of dykes in that country with the view to applying the same to a project for damming and draining Lake Boroullos, which is now under contemplation, and that then the above Ministry would decide whether to do the work, or concede it to a company. On making enquiries yesterday we were informed that there was no truth whatever in the rumour of any such intention on the part of the Government, and that if such were the case there is no need whatever for the studying of any system, since the work would be easy enough, and would simply be a repetition of that already successfully accomplished at Aboukir.

What is correct is that for some time, and until the recent decision of the Government not to sell any more lands until the whole question of the farther supply of water was finally settled, was made known, several offers were made by companies and private individuals for the purchase of the present marshy lands adjoining the lake. Sir Hanbury Brown. the former inspector general of irrigation for Lower Egypt, came out from England last winter, we believe on behalf of a syndicate which was desirous of acquiring some of these lands, but the decision we speak of put a stop to this as well as other similar projects. We understand that with an expenditure of from £10 to £15 per feddan the lands in this region could be rendered fit for cultivation, and it seems a pity, in our opinion, that some means cannot be devised whereby they could be brought under cultivation.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d'Hote Luncheons & Dinners
Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 8 TO 11.30 P.M
Delightful. Situation - Sea B?????.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
MAIL STEAMER ASHORE IN CANAL.
div.p: Suez, Sunday.

The outward bound Messageries Maritimes mail steamer Caledonien, owing to a breakdown of her steering gear, grounded in the Canal in the small Bitter lake last Friday evening at 8 o’clock. The powerful tug Titan was sent from Suez, but all efforts to refloat her were unsuccessful.

Yesterday afternoon, however, labourers and lighters were sent from Suez, and the vessel commenced discharging cargo, in the hopes that she would come off at high tide (9 o’clook last night), hut in spite of this, she is still fast in the same position. Fortunately the traffic is clear to the passing steamers.
Monday.

The Messageries Maritimes mail steamer Caledonien was refloated yesterday forenoon, after having discharged several hundred tons of cargo into lighters, which she is now reloading in the small Bitter lake.
The Caledonien apparently sustained no damage whatever, and is expected to come out of the Canal to-night.
BATTLESHIP FROM CHINA.
H.M.S. Glory arrived at Suez this afternoon from China and Colombo, and will probably enter the Canal this evening.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT LIMITED.
div.p: Mr. W. T. C. Beckett, M. Inst. C. E., the General Manager of the Corporation, is now en route for Egypt to take up his appointment there.
Orders for three locomotives for use on the Nile-Kbarga Railway have been placed wih Messrs. Nasmyth, Wilson and Co.

div.head: SUPPRESSION OF A NILE GAUGE.
div.p: The Mudir of Berber telegraphed on Friday from El Damir that by order of the Inspector General of Irrigation tor the Sudan the old gauge at Atbara has been suppressed since the 20th August, it being found unnecessary on account of its proximity to the Berber gauge, from which it is only 25 kilometres distant.

div.head: WORKMEN’S DWELLINGS.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary states that the Sanitary Administration is now drafting new regulations as to the construction of workmen’s dwellings. These regulations have been already submitted to the chief sanitary inspectors, and only await the return of Sir Horace Pinching who will submit them to the Contentieux. Meantime the draft regulations have been translated into Arabic, and the translations will be submitted to the criticism of the provincial sanitary authorities. The new regulations enact that anyone wishing to build workmen’s dwellings must follow their rules as to the hygienic construction thereof. Existing buildings will not be affected, the regulations only applying to new construotions. The Mixed Court of Appeal will give its views on the project in November, and the regulations will become law on January 1, 1906.

div.head: MILITARY INSPECTION IN CRETE.
div.p: Brigadier-General G. M Bullock, C.B., Commanding the Force in Egypt, accompanied by Captain H. B. P. L. Kennedy, 1st Bn. King’s Royal Rifles Corps, will leave Cairo to-morrow by the 9.30 a.m. train for Alexandria, where he will embark on the Khedivial steamer for passage to Crete, viâ Piraeus, on inspection duty. 2nd-Lieut. J. F. Hope, 1st Bn. King’s Royal Rifles Corps, will also form. one of the inspecting party.

div.head: ANOTHER NEW MOSS LINER
div.p: On Wednesday, 16th inst., Messrs. John Blumer and Co., Sunderland, launched a steamer built to the order of the Moss S.S. Co., Ltd., of Liverpool, for their Mediterranean line. She is of the spar deck type, riggged as a two masted schooner, with masts arranged to pass under the Manchester Canal bridges. She is fitted with handsome and roomy aooommodation for the captain and officers on the bridge deck, and also for a number of passengers.
The vessel is lighted throughout by electricity, the work being carried out by Messrs. H.T. Boothroyd, Hyslop and Co., Liverpool.

Both ship and engines are being constructed under the superintendence of Messrs. Wm. Esplen and Son, of Liverpool, and are built to the highest class of the British Corporation Registry, under the special survey of Mr. J. Frazer MacDonald, their Sunderland representative.
There was a large company present, including Mr. Wm. M. Moss, Mr. F. W. Moss (of Alexandria), Mr. John Esplen, Mr. and Mrs. Geo Clark, and Rev. J.O. Coop (of Liverpool).
The christening ceremony was gracefully performed by Miss Phyllis 0. E. Moss, of Alexandria, and the vessel received the name of Khephren.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss Liner Tabor, which sailed from Liverpool last Saturday, is dud at Alexandria on the 9th September with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE NOTES.
COINER ARRESTED
div.p: Constantinople, August 21.

A few days ago a certain Karo Aghanthropu, a Greek subject, was arrested at Pera. It appears that, three years ago, Karo made a business of coining at Alexandria, aided by a notorious expert in the art, named Alexandra He made a small fortune in the Egyptian seaport, and then left Egypt and proceeded to Constantinople, where he took np his abode in a house in the Rue Mezarlik.

A few mouths ago some unsuccessful speculations on the Galata Bourse swept away his ill-gotten gains, and be found himself obliged to return to his former trade, and had manufactured a large number of false coins when he was arrested.

div.head: CONSULAR AND DIPLOMATIC NEWS
div.p: M. Maximoff, ex Russian diplomatic agent at Cairo and at present minister at Cettinje, presented his credentials to Prinoe Nikita of Montenegro on the 17th inst Despatches from Cettinje state that the speeches uttered on the occasion were of a most cordial character.

M. Le Pescheux Duhantbonrg, the new French Vice-Consul at Salonika, has just arrived at the Macedonian port to enter on his new appointment The new Vice Consul is not unknown in Egypt, his first appointment, having been that of “Eléve-Chancelier” to the French Consulate at Cairo in 1894.

div.head: THE NEGUS’ BIRTHDAY.
div.p: The Sultan sent a warm message of congratulation to the Negus Menelik on his birthday, and received a cordial reply from the Abyssinian monarch. The Sultan also sent a congratulatory message to Ato Haile Mariam Pasha, head of the Abyssinian mission now at Constantinople.

div.head: AUSTRIAN BANK IN ABYSSINIA.
div.p: I am informed that Abdallah Pasha Sadik, envoy of the Negns Menelik, is treating with certain Austrian capitalists at Vienna for the formation of a new bank in Abyssinia with a capital of 18,000,000 kroner.

[Does not the concession granted to the National Bank of Egypt for the creation of the Bank of Abyssinia, assure that bank the monopoly of all banking business in the dominions of the Negus? Ed. E. G.]

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: A vocal and instrumental concert will be given at the San Stefano Casino on Thursday for the benefit of, M. A.. Bracale, when the well-known amateur violincellist, M. E. Cattaui, will take part. Mme. A. Bracale, who has a soprano voice of exceptional purity, and is well known both in Cairo and Alexandria, also appears on the programme, and amongs others we note M.M. Sodero, Romeo, Soriente, etc. The following is the programme of the concert, which will commence at 9.30 p.m.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sidky Pasha leaves Vienna for Buda-Pesth on the 5th prox. and will remain at the Magyar capital till the 18th prox., when he will leave for Egypt via Trieste, arriving at Alexandria in the 3rd week of September.
Leave of absence has been granted in extension to El Bimbashi Bethel, Artillery, and El Bimbashi Percival, D.S.O., Camel Corps, until the 6th and 25th September respectively.
Lieutenant L. W. Bird, 2nd battalion Royal Berks., has been granted extension of leave until October 31.
M. Gennadis arrived from Cairo last night.

News has been received from Rome to the effect that Mgr. Giannini, Apostolic Delegate at Beyrout will be appointed patriarch of Jerusalem and will be replaced at Beyrout by Mgr. Aurelio Briante, Apostolio Delegate for Egypt and Arabia. The Rev. Father Remigio Barsotti of the Franoiscan Order will replace Mgr. Aurelio Briante in Egypt and Arabia.

div.head: CRICKET.
A. C. C. v. ROYAL BERKS. REGIMENT.
div.p: Played on Saturday August. 26. The regiment won the toss bat started badly, losing two wickets for ten runs. Some free hitting by Capt. Moore and Major Arbuthnot, however, improved matters, the latter being especially strong on the leg side and hitting nine fours. Corporal Morrison, Sergt Godrey and Mr. Robertson all made some resistance to the bowling, and the innings reached the total of 150. Graves came off beet of the A C. C. bow'ers, but the absence of H. B. Carver and Maclaren was decidedly felt. The fielding was uneven, bat Dawson was in good form behind the wicket The A.C.C., despite some good hits by Macaulay, did not begin any too well and three wickets were down for 32. R. Carver and Graves added 65 runs, and the former was fifth out for a freely-hit 45. H. P. Carver soon made the match secure, scoring very freely for 51. His innings included no less than twelve fours, his off-side strokes being most brilliant The innings finally dosed for 191, the A.C.C. thus winning by 41 runs. Score and bowling analysis:—

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: The members of the above club met on Saturday last The weather being favorable, a very pleasant afternoon was spent, although the attendance was under strength. A temporary spring board was erected for the afternoon, and the members derived great pleasure from the diving that could be indulged in.
Members meet as usual on Saturday next.

div.head: BRITISH RIFLE CLUB (ALEX.)
div.p: On Saturday last Mr. G. D. Lovell won the Milton Bronze Badge with a total soore of 78 points, namely 28 at 200yds. 25 at 500 yds., and 25 at 60u yds. This was undoubtedly a good shoot as the weather was not altogether favorable to good shooting, the wind being at times changeable. There will be no practioe next Saturday.

div.head: La Daira Sauieh
div.p: Votre estimable Journal a publié la semaine écoulée un apercu sur la New daïra Sanieh, que la presse égyptienne a largement reproduit et d'apres lequel la valeur de l'Action de cette Société serait au ler Octobre prochain, (soit dans un mois), de £29.9.7- en ne tenant pas compte de divers facteurs qui ne peuvent être fixés des aujourd'hui, et qui justifieraient le prix de £ 31 et même £ 32.-

Cet apercu, qui a tout l'air d'être, par la précision de ses chiffres un communique officiel de la New Daira Cy., aurait atteint son but, qui était évidemment de tranquilliser les Actionnaires de la dite Société, si le lendemain du jour de sa publication tous les journaux locaux n'eussent annoucé que les membres de la Famille Khéhiviale intentaient un proces conjointement au Gouvernement Egyptien, a la New Daïra Cy., et au Crédit Foncier Egyptien.

On assure d'autre part au public, code en main, que les Actionnaires de la Daïra n'ont rien a perdre dans ce procés, le Gouvernement qui a vendu a cette Société les terrains en contestation étant largement solvable, et que tout au plus, la liquidation de la New Daïra purrait subir un retard de quelques mois.

Toutes ces nouvelles contradictoires ne peuvent que créer sur place un malaise qui, portant sur une valeur locale de tout premier ordre occasionne de dangereux hauts et bas sur le marché. C'est pourquoi je me permets de vous adresser la présente pour vous demander, Monsieur le Directeur, si vous ne trouves pas comme moi et beaucoup de porteurs d'Actions de la Daïra Sanieh, que cette Société est tenue, a la veille de sa Liquidation, de donne au public non pas des communications plus on moins officieuses, mais un exposé officiel tant pour ce qui est de sa liquidation prochaine et de son entente avec le Crédit Foncier, que pour ce qui concerne le proces qui de pres ou de loin la touche nécessairement. Un exposé officiel de la Société, seul, mettrait fin aux fluctuations du marché qui peuvent être dangereuses pour une valeur aussi importante que celle qui nous occupe.
Veuillez agréer, Monsieur le Directeur, mes salutations empresséss.

div.head: Ministere Des Travaux Publics
div.p: L'adjudication du 9 aout 1905, relative aux travaux de réfection de Bahr-el-Bachawat, province de Fayoum, a été approuvée en faveur de M. C. A. Cangos, au prix de L.E. 9.750.

L'adjudication du 9 aout 1905, relative aux travaux de maconnerie a exécuter dans le Bahr-el-Bachawat, y compris le pont-route de Khourchid, province de Fayoum, a été approuv´ en faveur de M. Naûm A. Khalaf, au prix de 2.197 L.E. 744 milliemes.
Les sommes ci-dessus ne sont pas définitives; elles seront arrêtées lors de l'établissement de la derniere situation de l'entreprise.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché de ce matin a été plutôt calme. Les transactions se sont, en effet, limitées aux Agricoles et aux Estates.
On a fait 5 a 6000 de ces derniers a un prix variant de 1 3/32 a 1 3/16. La clôture a lieu a 1 5/32, en bonne tendance.

Grand émoi sur les Suereies a la nouvelle du suicide M. Crosnier. Le cours est tombé de 155 a 110, a repris un moment a 118 et clôturé a 112. A Paris la valeur a fléchi de 155 a 105 et la Raffinerie Say a baissé de 400 franos.
L'Agricole continue a hausser de 14 5/16 a 14 3/8 avec affaires, ainsi que la Béhéra de 43 3/4 a 43 7/8.
Le Trust reprend de 1 9/32 a 1 5/16 et les Privilégiées Tramways de 158 a 159.
Par contre, la Banque Nationale réactionne de 27 13/16 a 27 3/4 l'ancienue et de 27 3/4 a 27 23/32 la nouvelle, et la Khedivial Mail de 21/ a 20/9.
Le reste du marché reste stationnaire ….…

div.head: Cotton Trade Wages
div.p: The avoidance of a long and disastrous strike in the cotton trade is a tribute to the good sense and sagacity of employers as well as of employed. The men gain a concession which is perhaps not unwarrantad by the state of the trade during the past year, and it must be remembered that they suffered severely during the recent crises, not by reduction in the rate of wages but by the diminution of their earning power owing to the necessity to work short time for the good of the trade as a whole. The self sacrifice of the operatives at a time when it was necessary to take combined action no doubt entitled their present claims to consideration. On the other hand, it must not be forgotten that had there been no agreement just now, had the operatives pressed their claim and insisted upon a strike, the situation would have suited many of the employers very well. The limitation of cotton buying is a very desirable object at this moment, for it is the most effectual way to check the market mani- pillations of unscrupulous speculators who have forced up the price of the raw material upon exaggerated reports A week or two ago the Committee of the International Federation of Cotton Spinners urged every spinner in Europe and America, inasmuch as they controlled enough cotton to fulfil their engagements for three or four months ahead, to make no further purchases of precent crop cotton except for immediate needs until the arrival of the new crop at the end of October. A strike would have put such purchasing out of the question in England, and so would have brought down the price of the raw material, which is now unnaturally high. But the remedy can now be applied without any of the unavoidable evils attendant on a labour war, and all those en- gaged in the trade may be congratulated on the happy issue to which they have agreed.

It is thirteen year since there was a really serious labour dispute in the cotton trade, and that disastrous lockout led to the adoption of the Brooklands agreement, which has worked very happily ever since. There has been grumbling on both sides occasionally, but on the whole the basis of conciliation therein arrived at has furnished a working model which might well be adopted in other trades. Strong men on both sides have met together to consider difficulties, and in the light of reason they have generally been swept away. The men have agreed to work short time rather than suffer a reduction in the standard rate of wages, but they are well aware that the rate of wages must to a large extent determine the prices of the goods to be sold, and as they are all well acquainted with the intricacies of this most complicated industry, they are usually wise enough to refrain from harassing proposals which may jeopardise its welfare. Thus ther was a general opinion when the unions put forward their demand for an in- crease in the rate some time ago that the leaders might have exercised more patience, inasmuch as he trade was again passing through a critical period supervening on a run of great prosperity. A delay of three months would have been prudent but, happily, the machinery of conciliation has prevailed, and the masters have seen fit to give the men, less, indeed, than they demanded, but enough to preserve the peace, though at the same time not so much as to create a serious inconvenience in the market.

It is, of course, very difficult to lay down a plan of universal application to all conditions in an industry in which those conditions are constantly changing. The issue between the employers and the operatives is to arrive at at standard wage applicable both to good and bad times. A few years ago Mr. C. W. Macara, the President of the Federation of Cotton Spin- ners, and also of the International Federation, a man of great ability and statesmanlike qua- lities, perfected a scheme for the automatic regulation of wages which would have render- ed the Brooklands Agreement complete, and would have met every state of the trade. To consider the scheme no fewer than nineteen conferences took place between special commit- tees of the Federation and of the Operatives' Amalgamations. The employers' plan provided for the investigations by outside experts, in whose appointment both sides should have a voice, of the actual state of the trade, and according to the result of that investigation wages would be adjusted, and the operatives would sercure an equitable share of the profits of the indus- try. In Lancashire the plan was generally believed to be fair and just, and Mr. Macara still thinks that if it had been adopted it would ahve removed for all time the possiblility of a conflict between capital and labour, and would have prevented the crisis through which the industry has just passed. Unhappily, the operative rejected that plan, and though the present difficulty has been overcome, there is nothing to prevent it from being raised again next March, when the present settlement comes up for reconsideration.

The need for some such automatic agency of adjustment is shown by the facts of the pre- sent situation. For three years past the spin- ning industry has had to work short time, and last year the restriction was in operation for many months. This was very hard for the operatives, whose earnings were thus diminish- ed; but it was no less hard for the employers, who made heavy losses all the time. During this period the public organs of the operatives more than once referred to the forbearance of the employers in not demanding a reduction of the rate of wages, and actually declared that when good times did return the employers would be entitled as a reward for this forbear- ance to great consideration from the work- people. Yet, after very few months of good trade the demand for an advance of 5 percent was put forward. Thus, while the operatives hold that reductions in wages are no remedy for bad trade, and that short time is the true cure, no sooner does the good time come than they insist on sharing in the profits it brings. Such a doctrine the employers felt bound to re- and though they have given way to a certain extent, it would be foolish to assume that they accept the proposition that wages must not fall in adversity, but must be raised in pros- perity. The operatives appear to be fixed in their policy of minumun living wage plus a demand for a share in any increased normal profits. This wage must be recognised as a fixed charge on the industry, if trade declines wages must not be reduced, and employers must take this fixed charge into account when making their prices. The propsition that there shall be no reduction in bad times, but that there shall be an increase in good times, is certain to be a bone of contention in the future, and it would be well for the trade if upon a certain fixed standard a sliding scale or other means of autmatic adjustment could be applied. In his appeal to the conference which has just discussed this question, the Lord Mayor of Manchester, Sir Thomas Shann, appealed for a settlement , "even if it should be only temporary settlement, to afford time for the settin up of machinery which will automatically prevent the recurrence of a situa- tion such as that at which you have now arrived." It may be that such an agreement will not be reached until after a severe struggle in the near future, but the hard-headed Lancashire men should be able to see the wisdom of adopting the plan, which will put an end to all disputes it it be faithfully observ- ed. If the operatives are right in demanding a share in their employers' prosperity they must be prepared to suffer with them in periods of adversity, with probably a fixed minimum. By give and take on these lines the great industry may be saved from disastrous conflicts, and it's future prosperity will be substantially assured.

div.head: JAPAN'S SECOND-HAND FLEET
div.p: It has now been ascertained (says the "Times" correspondent at Tokio) that the Russion warshipss at Port Arthur were not blown up or sunk by gun fire. The Russians opened the Kingston valves, having previously greased or otherwise protected the machinery and vital parts of the vessels.
The following are the Russian warships of the original Pacific Fleet which have been or may be salved by the Japanese:
Battleships.-Poltava and Peresviet-re-floated and navigable by their own engines; Retvisan and Pobieda-do be raised and fit for service shortly.
Cruisers Bayan and Pallada-refloated.
Of the vessels reported sunk by shell fire at Port Arthur the protected cruiser Amur alone remaine unaccounted for. The cruiser Variag, which was sunk at Chemulpo, has also been refloated.

div.head: Bakshish In Turkey.
div.p: Italians travelling in Turkey send home indignant complaints, which are published in the Press, of the shameless way in which the examination of travellers' luggage at the frontier Custom houses is made the occasion for exacting "bakshish". The grumblings, ill-tempers, interrogations, and even open insult to which the traveller is subject can only be faintly imagined by one who has not been subjected to the ordeal-until, quite wearied out, the helpless voyager bethinks him of the Turk's proverbially itching palm, and places a few coins in the hand of his tormentor. Then vilifications instantly give way to the most profuse courtesies. Even harmless picture postcards can be utilised as a means of extortion.

div.head: TSUSHIMA BUBBLES BURST
div.p: A survivor ofthe battle of Tsushima, in passing through Moscow, told a local paper that it was not true that the Russian crews were in a state of mutiny before the battle, being worn out by the hardships of the voyage. In reality, they had splendid weather throughout, and arrived at the Straits confident of victory, but "the first day's fight convinced our men that our shells, compared with those of the Japanese, were beneath criticism, and on the second day the overwhelming force of the enemy fired at a distance beyond our range, without taking into account the fact that many of our shells did not burst. The only choice lay between sinking the ships and surrendering. Why admiral Nebogatoff chose the latter is impossibly to say."

div.head: ISLAM IN AFRICA
div.p: It is long now since M. Benger ceased to be popularly known as an African explorer. He is now director of African affairs at the French Colonial Office, and in the course of an interview upon the progress of civilisation, he has drawn attention to a remarkable fact in African development, which has its significance for Great Britain as well as for France. It is that the missionary seal of Islam is at least equal to that of the Christian churches, and is infinitely more successful. Fetish tribes accept the Koran wholesale without difficulty, while the Christian missionary has to be content with individual converts few and far between. Some observers regard this as a danger, but M. Benger has no fear on the score of Islam, even should it dominate the whole of Africa.

div.head: EXTRAORDINARY CHARGE.
div.p: VERB. SAP. SATIS.

Capt. T. W. W - of the 14th Hussars, was before Mr. Curtis Bonnett, at Westminster, last Tuesday, accused of having assaulted Louise Adams, a little girl of 14, in a first-class carriage on the District Railway.-Mr. Philip Conway defended.

The girl, who was nicely dressed, and gave evidence with remarkable self-possession, deposed the accused was a friend of her mother's at Cairo. In july witness came to England with her mother, and since then defendant had been out with them. On the previous afternoon the captain met them at Victoria Station, and while her mother was away he suggested that they should have a ride to Charing cross on the District Railway. They entered an empty first-class carriage, and defendant almost at once assaulted her. Owing to her resistance he got angry with her, and smacked her face with the back of his hand. Her nose bled slightly. Defendant pressed her to sit on his knee, and assaulted her. They went to gether as far as Temple Station, and walked back to Charing-cross, where she met her mother. In the absence for a minute of defendant, she told her mother her part of the story. After that, all three of them proceeded in a cab to Earl's-court Exhibition. While sht captain was making a purchase she told the remainder of her story to her mother. They strolled together about the Exhibition after having tea, and then took a cab to Victoria Station. There they dined at a restaurant. Late at night they all went to Westminster police-station, and defendant was charged at the instance of witness's mother.
Mr. Conway said he should reserve his cross-examination.

The mother of the little girl, a showily-dressed woman, deposed that her name was Malca Adams, and she was proprietress of a fashionable buffet at Cairo. Recently she brought her husband, a harmless imbecile, to Bursted, Sussex, where he had very rich relatives. She had known defendant about two years. She met him with other British officers in Cairo, and had lived with him in a flat in that town. She left her husband because she fell in love with defendant. Eventually she had to part with defendant because he came to England. She had a large sum of money to give up his love-letters, and signed an agreement last March not to molest him. When she brought her husband to England on July 14th she thought she would like to see the captain again. So on her arrival at Dover she telephoned to defendant at Folkestone to meet her.
Mr. Bennett: This was the first thing you did after the agreement?

Witness: Yes. We had been on corresponding terms, and I was very fond of him. He took me to a hall at Cairo, and we were the best of friends. We agreed to be "platonic friends." He came over to see me.
Mr. Curtis Bennett: Now let us come to the events of yesterday.

Witness: I was going back to Cairo, and lost the 11 o'clock Continental train from Viotoris. I was there with the child, and the captain was going to see us off. It was through waiting for the defendant to say good-bye that we lost the train. My luggage had all gone on to Paris. When the train went out, I left my little girl with defendant. I went to buy a phonograph to take back to my buffet at Cairo. On returning I found defendant and my daughter lunching together in a restaurant. I was angry with Louise for not staying where I left her. I left Victoria about 2 o'clock, and did not take my little girl with me because she was lunching and because the Captain was such an old confidential friend. We arranged to meet later at the Charing-cross Station. The captain and the girl arrived there punetually, and at the first opportunity Louise said: "Mother, I want to tell you something very serious. We went underground, and Billy was going to assault me." Just then the defendant came up and remarked to me: "What are you so cross for?" I said: "Nothing," for I wanted to hear the rest of the story from the child before I tackled him. Then we got in a cab and went to the Earl's Court Exhibition. There, while defendant was looking at an exhibit, I walked away with the child, and questioned her, when she told me the full details. The child also said that he threatened to through the window, and that she was awfully frightened from Earl's Court they drove to a restaurant opposite Victoria Station. There witness said to defendant, "What have you been at with Louise." He said, "Has she been saying anything - I'll kill that brat." When wwe left the restaurant it was nine o'clock, and I said I was going to report the matter to the police. Prisoner walked away. I told prisoner that if he did not walk quietly to the station we should have a scene in the street. They walked to the police-station, and she preferred the charge.
Mr. Curtis Bennett said he did not think it was necessary to hear more of this most remarkably story. He did not believe one word the woman had said, and it seemed that her object was to blackmail.
Mr. Conway: Of course, the defendant says there is not one tittle of truth in these allegations. It is a monstrous thing he should have been locked up on such a charge.
Mr. Curtis Bennett: He has nobody to blame but himself for the company he keeps. Now he is discharged.
"The Globe."

div.head: WORLD'S RICHEST LIBRARY.
div.p: The richest library in the world is the National Library of Paris, founded by Louis XIV., which contains 1,400,000 volumes, 300,000 pamphlets and small works, 175,000 manuscripts, 800,000 maps and atlases, and 150,000 medals.

div.head: WOMAN'S PROGRESS IN THE HAREM.
div.p: Miss Margaret Macgregor, under the heading "Behind the Lattice and the Veil," gives some very interesting facts about the Turkish woman of today, in the August number of "Good Words." She shows by photograph, as well as by letterpress, that the yashmak of today half reveals as well as half conceals the charms behind:-

The Sultan is continually issuing orders enforcing the wearing of the thick black veil that effectually hides those charms, but these orders are perhaps obeyed for a day, and then the Turkish beauty again brings out her thinnest and most transparent ganze.

Just as her veil fails to hide her face, so also her trim black tchartchaff fails in its end, that of hiding her figure, and it is today taking lines that are distinctly Parisian, instead of being the shapeless black cloak that her grandmother wore over her baggy trousers.

Beneath the tchartchaff almost every Turkish woman is a European, and the orthodox trousers of the Moslem women are practically never seen. It is Paris and Vienna that supply the gowns of the ladies of the grand harems, while cheap Manchester cottons in the befreilled blouses of loud patterns peep out from under the tcharchaffs of the less wealthy.

As soon as you enter a dames turques your fellow-passengers will at once throw back their veils, and devour every detail of your costume, and before you are seated you will probably be asked how much you paid for the material of your dress, nor will they scruple to take it in their hands and examine and discuss its quality. They will find out how that frill is put on, and this tuck arranged, not improbably will they pick up your skirt to see what your petticoat is like! You will then be asked whether you are married or not, and if you are married how many children you have, what you husband's occupation is, and wht income he has!
And all these questions are not impertinent in their eyes, but rather a flattering interest in your affairs, or so you must regard them.

"Harem life is simple, unalloyed dulness," wanting now mostly the excitement of polygamy. The modern Turk "finds one wife as much as he can manage-financially speaking." Respect for parents seems urged to an extreme: -

"A man can get another wife, but he cannot get another mother," is the Turk's explanation of putting his mother before his wife, and as it is the accepted order of things, the wife does not feel aggrieved.
But the new order is steadily victorious. Even in the furnishing of the harem the picturesque East is giving place to the sombre West:-

It is usually Europeanized until it has no touch of the East, and is only a travesty of the taste of the West. The rugs and hangings and divans are all superseded by linoleums and muslim curtains and velvet upholstered chairs! The wall-papers are in colouring and pattern that you would have charged for your servants' bedrooms twenty years ago! The rooms are more like the show-rooms of an upholsterer's than the lived-in rooms of a home, excepting that the modern upholsterer is artistic.

The Turkish women have lost all their own Oriental picturesquences, and have not yet gained that indefinable charm that belongs to cultivated women of the West. Many Turkish women are highly educated; they read and speak, perhaps, English and French, they are often good musicians, and usually beautiful workers, but all those little graces that reval a woman in a house are entirely wanting in an Eastern harem. The women check all their natural Oriental taste and strive to be European, and the result is pitiable. They have given up their beautiful Eastern embroidary for crude European crewel work on satin.
The Sultan is continually repressing any sign of emancipation in the Turkish women, but apparently the woman is more than a match for the Sultan.

Ces droits de prefererice out ete reserves au prix de 810 francs par action de 500 francs fiberee de quart (soit, en deduisant les 375 francs restant a appeler, 435 francs, prix conrenu avec la Societe Egyptienne de la Daïra Sanieh), jouissance du 1er Novembre 1905, savoir:

(a) A concurrence de 100,000 actions aux porteurs des Actions anciennes dana la proportion des titres possedes par eux, soit a raison d'une action nouvelle pour deux actions anciennes, sans attribution de fraction:

(b) A concurrence de 100,000 actions aux porteurs des parts de fondation dans la proportion des titres possedes par eux soit a raison de 50 Actions nouvelles pour une part de fondation ou 5 actions nouvelles par dixiéme de part de fondation.
Le prix a verser, fixe, ainsi qu'il est dit plus haut, a 810 francs, moins 375 francs restant a appeler, soit net 435 francs eat payable comme suit:
